metadata.sermon_title: A City Hard to Love . . . but Loved
metadata.sermon_start_end: Palm Sunday was a big day in the life of Jesus. He had finally arrived in Jerusalem, the target of all his travels. He had brought his disciples along with him. He was met, as you know, by enthusiastic crowds. The crowds anticipated that he would be the one [...] It is his work. It is our work. It is the work of love that makes all things new. Hosanna!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon utilizes two distinct passages from Luke but treats them as thematic illustrations for a broader discourse on 'the city.' It fails to identify what is unique to these specific pericopes that cannot be found elsewhere. The text becomes a springboard for sociological reflection rather than a recreation of the Word.
quotes: In a second text, Luke 19:41–44 it is reported...
My assignment concerns love of the city.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on one pericope and extract its unique theological DNA. Avoid treating the Bible as a collection of 'clues' for a pre-determined theme.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is an attempt to ground the text in the historical tension between Galilee and Jerusalem. The preacher identifies the political weight of 'Herod' and 'the fox.' However, the exegesis is quickly modernized into sociological categories (media, banks, university) which risks distorting the original context.
quotes: Galilee is not really a territory. It is rather a social attitude and condition.
He addresses the temple priests and the learned scribes and the king and the money men.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the linguistic and theological analysis of the 'lament' form in Luke 13. Move beyond modern sociological parallels to the specific covenantal failure of Jerusalem.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is contemporary but tends toward 'general truths' about urban life (sexism, racism, economics). While concrete in naming social ills, it lacks the spiritual specificity Dekker demands. It feels more like a social manifesto than a word that 'expounds' the hearer's heart.
quotes: But it could have been any city, including Louisville or Cincinnati...
We can name some of the demons... forces such as sexism, racism, exploitative money.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the application to the specific spiritual condition of the congregation rather than general societal critiques that apply to 'any city'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a somewhat traditional 'then and now' structure. While it attempts to bridge the gap by saying 'we are city people,' the transition is abrupt. The hearer is an observer of Jesus' actions rather than being 'expounded' by the text itself.
quotes: Now I know that this struggle in old Jerusalem has nothing to do with you or with me. Except that we are city people.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'bridge' method. Let the exposition of the text immediately reveal the present reality of the hearer.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon is heavily weighted toward a horizontal view of misery (social injustice). Redemption is presented as human action (the church as an 'engine' for change). The vertical dimension—misery before God and redemption through Christ's substitution—is largely absent.
quotes: I often think how hopeless the city would be without the church.
It is our work like it was his work.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Reclaim the 'extra nos' (outside ourselves) nature of redemption. The church is not the engine of salvation; Christ is.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: There is no sense of ultimate loss or the 'narrow way.' The 'demons' are social constructs, and the 'future' is a social possibility. The seriousness of God's judgment or the possibility of being eternally lost is bypassed for a message of social 'hope.'
quotes: Where Jesus comes, the city has a chance.
Hosanna is hope. It is hope that overpowers fear.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the reality that Jerusalem *was* lost because it did not recognize the time of its visitation. The 'two ways' must involve a real crisis of choice.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the protagonist, but he functions more as an ethical model or a 'street smart' activist than as the Divine Savior. The doctrine of the two natures is not felt; he is a 'rabble-rousing outsider.' Grace is framed as social 'second chances' rather than the ontological salvation of the sinner.
quotes: Jesus is into that. He used what he had left of his life... and so might we!
It is our work. It is the work of love that makes all things new.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Shift Christ from being an example of 'tough love' to being the 'telos'—the one who does for the city what the city (and the church) cannot do for itself.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1450 words, the sermon lasts about 14-15 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for theological depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the substantive theological reflection to meet the 20-minute threshold, allowing the text to breathe beyond social commentary.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria by prioritizing horizontal social ethics over vertical theological proclamation. It treats the biblical text as a thematic resource for a discourse on urban sociology. The 'three parts' are reduced to social misery and human-led restoration, while the 'two ways' and the radicality of grace are obscured by a call to activism.
strengths: Clear attempt to make the biblical narrative contemporary and relevant to the hearers' environment.
Strong use of imagery (trench coats, dark suits) to illustrate the political tension of the Passion narrative.
weaknesses: Duration is significantly below the 20-minute requirement for depth.
Theological 'theft' where the church/humanity replaces Christ as the agent of redemption.
Lack of specificity regarding what this particular text says that no other text says.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker's theses; it is a religious-ethical speech on social responsibility. It lacks the 'present of revelation' where the specific Word of God judges and saves the hearer.
